review.title: Empirical Evaluation of Tree distances for Parser Evaluation
review.abstract: In this empirical study, I compare various tree distance measures -- originally developed in computational biology for the purpose of tree comparison -- for the purpose of parser evaluation. I will control for the parser setting by comparing the automatically generated parse trees from the state-of-the-art parser Charniak, 2000) with the gold-standard parse trees. The article describes two different tree distance measures (RF and QD) along with its variants (GRF and GQD) for the purpose of parser evaluation. The article will argue that RF measure captures similar information as the standard EvalB metric (Sekine and Collins, 1997) and the tree edit distance (Zhang and Shasha, 1989) applied by Tsarfaty et al. (2011). Finally, the article also provides empirical evidence by reporting high correlations between the different tree distances and EvalB metric's scores.
histories: Submitted to satisfy partial requirements for Statistical Parsing course
Submitted to satisfy partial requirements for Statistical Parsing course
review.COMMENTS: Submitted to satisfy partial requirements for Statistical Parsing course

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Historical linguists as well as evolutionary biologists use the tree approach to capture language and biological analyses, using statistical and quantitative techniques to derive relationships based on sequence data: linguistic units such as lexemes, grammatical markers and gene sequences (Levinson and Gray, 2012; Felsenstein, 2004). In the case of historical linguistics, inferred language trees are compared with trees derived from the application of the comparative method (Hoenigswald, 1973). Wichmann et al. (2011) and Pompei et al. (2011) compare different tree distance measurements to compare different language relationships. In the related field of computational linguistics, grammatical relationships between words are captured in a sentence by rooted, metrized trees.

sections.heading: 2 Tree distances
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 2.1 Basics
sections.text: In this subsection, I define basic symbols and terms. An input line I consists of words w1 · · · wn of length n. A parse tree T defines the relationship between these words. According to Goodman (1996), a tree T consists of triples (s, t, X), where s to t are consecutive words defined by an internal node called X. According to Goodman (1996), the appropriate criteria for an automatic parse tree Ta with its gold standard tree Tg are defined in terms of blank precision (P) and callback (R). Ng is the number of internal nodes in Tg and Na the number of internal nodes in Ta. Leave B = | (s, t, X): (s, t, X).

sections.heading: 2.2 RF (Robinson-Foulds) Distance
sections.text: In fact, it is not that it is a reactionary act, but an attempt to transform itself into a reactionary movement. (...) It is not that there will be a reactionary movement. (...) It is as if it will be a reactionary movement. (...) It is as if it will be a reactionary movement. (...) It is as if it will be a reactionary movement. (...) It is as if it will be a reactionary movement. (...) It is as if it will be a reactionary movement. (...) It is as if it will be a reactionary movement. (...) It is as if it will be a reactionary movement. "

sections.heading: 2.3 Quartet distance
sections.text: A quartet is defined as a set of four leaves selected from a series of leaves without substitution; a tree of n leaves has (n 4) quartets in total; a quartet defined on four leaves a, b, c, d can have four different topologies: ab | bd, ad | bc, and ab · cd; the first three topologies have an internal edge that separates two pairs of leaves; such quartets are called butterflies; the fourth quartet has no internal edge and is known as a star quartet; and a parse tree can have an internal node that is a parent to at least four leaves.

sections.heading: 3 Parser and dataset
sections.text: For our experiments, I use the Charniak parser to analyze the 2416 sentences in Section 23 of Penn TreeBank. From these parses, I discarded any parses with a sentence length of less than 4. After this step, I had 2378 parses left. I also converted the automatic and gold parses to NEWICK format (Rock, 2004). The NEWICK format is a bracket format to represent trees and uses, "symbol to separate adjacent leaves; opening and closing brackets. I also removed the POS tag for each word. This step removes all nodes that have a grade of 2. Therefore, a definitive NEWICK format tree consists solely of brackets and words. I use the EvalB program to calculate the sentence level precision and retrieve ratings. 2Available at http: / / birc.au.dk / diqst / software.

sections.heading: 4 Results
sections.text: Our first hypothesis is that RFD correlates to a large extent with the F-scores, based on the similarity in the formulas shown in Section 2.2. Accordingly, Pearson's r between RFD and F-scores is − 0.9. We attribute the difference to the handling of the top brackets. We ignore the top bracket enclosing the root symbol, while EvalB includes it in the calculation. GRFDs and F-scores also show a correlation of − 0.82. The correlation is likely to be negative, as F-score is a measure of similarity, while RFD is a distance metric. I have also checked the correlation of QD and GQD with F-scores. The correlation is quite high: − 0.73 and − 0.68, respectively. I have also calculated the correlation between the four different distance scales. The correlation is shown in Table 1.The measures that correlate QD with trees that correlate are very different from 2006, but not based on the observation of trees.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion and future work
sections.text: In this article, I have described two popular parameters for tree distances from computer biology and used them for parser evaluation purposes. I observe that the parameters for the performance of a single parser correlate to a large extent with each other. I also argued that QD and generalized parameters for tree distances are very suitable for parser evaluation tasks, as the gold parses can have internal nodes with degrees greater than 2. I also argued that RF distance measurements do the same thing as the distance for the calculation of blank accuracies. This hypothesis is supported by the high Pearson-r. In the future, we plan to test the various parameters on other standard parameters.

sections.heading: Acknowledgements
sections.text: I thank Richard Johansson for providing the binaries of Charniak Parser. I thank Prasanth Kolachina and Richard Johansson for interesting discussions. I thank Joakim Nivre for his patience and encouragement throughout the process of experimenting and writing reports.

I will control for the parser setting by comparing the automatically generated parse trees from the stateof-the-art parser (Charniak, 2000) with the gold-standard parse trees. The article describes two different tree distance measures (RF and QD) along with its variants (GRF and GQD) for the purpose of parser evaluation. The article will argue that RF measure captures similar information as the standard EvalB metric (Sekine and Collins, 1997) and the tree edit distance (Zhang and Shasha, 1989) applied by Tsarfaty et al. (2011). Finally, the article also provides empirical evidence by reporting high correlations between the different tree distances and EvalB metric’s scores.
In the case of historical linguistics, inferred language trees are compared with trees inferred from application of the comparative method (Hoenigswald, 1973).
Moving along the spectrum, trees by themselves play a major role in computer science (Bille, 2005).
Goodman (1996) formalizes the PARSEVAL metrics (Abney et al., 1991) in the context of constituency-based parsing.

In the case of historical linguistics, inferred language trees are compared with trees inferred from application of the comparative method (Hoenigswald, 1973). Wichmann et al. (2011) and Pompei et al.

In the case of historical linguistics, inferred language trees are compared with trees inferred from application of the comparative method (Hoenigswald, 1973). Wichmann et al. (2011) and Pompei et al. (2011) compare different tree distance measures for comparing different language relationship inference techniques.
Moving along the spectrum, trees by themselves play a major role in computer science (Bille, 2005). Goodman (1996) formalizes the PARSEVAL metrics (Abney et al.
Following Goodman (1996), a tree T is composed of triples (s, t,X) where, s to t are consecutive words dominated by an internal node labeled as X.

Following Goodman (1996), a tree T is composed of triples (s, t,X) where, s to t are consecutive words dominated by an internal node labeled as X. Following Goodman (1996), the matching criteria for an automatic parse tree Ta with its gold standard tree Tg is defined in terms of unlabeled precision (P ) and recall (R).

It can be easily seen that RF distance is related to tree edit distance used in Tsarfaty et al. (2011). RF distance works in terms of internal edges whereas, tree edit distance works in terms of node insertion, deletion, and substitution.
GRFD, as introduced by Pompei et al. (2011), relaxes the strict equality condition of bipartitions with compatibility criterion.
Another possible distance is the quartet distance which measures the distance between two trees in terms of the number of different quartets between the two trees (Estabrook et al., 1985).
Christiansen et al. (2006) developed a fast algorithm that runs in O(n2d2) in time, and needs O(n2) in terms of space.
To this end, Pompei et al. (2011) defined a new measure known as GQD (Generalized QD) to discount the presence of star quartets in Tg.
